page.title: 04ECOLOGY OF THE RIVER DANE
page.content: Meandering through pastureland, the River Dane is subject to constant erosion and deposition of pebbles, gravel and silt. The river bank holds the remains of crack willow, felled because of their age, with little evidence of re-planting. Sand martins, kingfishers, water voles and water rats inhabit the river bank. An abundance of shepherd's purse, nettles, wild rhubarb and various grasses shelter a varied insenct life. Following the basic course of the river, a rough public footpath cuts through scattered deciduous woodlands of ash, oak, lime, sycamore and beech. Enlarged fields are bounded by a network of hawthorn and elder hedges filled with wild rose, bramble and vetch. Squirrels, weasels, rabbits, foxes, shrews, field mice are all inhabitants of the environment.
